This water is easily contaminated with bacteria that can cause diarrhea and other water-borne diseases, meaning that Ebby and her family may fall sick and become unable to work or attend school.

Ebby runs a small business, but has also volunteered her time to be the promoter for a new chlorine dispenser program that enables her community to drink safe water and stay healthy. Ebby and other promoters in her community (including Joy, Jackson, Samson and Beverlyne) need a loan to cover the costs of installing and maintaining chlorine dispensers at the water sources in the area. Ebby will encourage the community to treat their water with the dispenser, and refill the dispenser with chlorine as needed. She wants to be a promoter because she loves giving back to the community. Ebby believes that the dispenser will improve the health status of her community.

The Kiva loan will be repaid by Evidence Action (www.evidenceaction.org) on behalf of the community, through the sale of carbon credits. Using the chlorine dispenser generates carbon credits by avoiding the need to boil water to make it safe to drink. The sale of carbon credits, to organizations and individuals wanting to reduce their carbon footprint, will be used to repay Kiva lenders and also to make sure that Ebby’s community can have access to safe water now and in the future.

loans.use: to ensure that the community has access to safe drinking water via chlorine dispensers

loans.name: Dina's Group

texts.en:
75-year-old Dina is friendly, goal-oriented, reliable and well-liked. She has 5 children (2 daughters aged 29 and 12 years; and 3 sons aged 25, 18 and 11 years). She lives in Shihanjiro B village in Vihiga, Kenya. Shihanjiro B village does not have a piped water supply, so the community collects their water from a protected spring. This water is easily contaminated with bacteria that can cause diarrhea and other water-borne diseases, meaning that Dina and her family may fall sick and become unable to work or attend school.

Dina is currently enjoying her retirement from work, but has volunteered her time to be the promoter for a new chlorine dispenser program that enables her community to drink safe water and stay healthy. Dina and other promoters in her community (including Janet, Millicent, Miriam and Gideon) need a loan to cover the costs of installing and maintaining chlorine dispensers at the water sources in the area. Dina will encourage the community to treat their water with the dispenser, and refill the dispenser with chlorine as needed. She wants to be a promoter because she wants to help her community drink safe water. She believes that the dispenser will be good for their health.

The Kiva loan will be repaid by Evidence Action (www.evidenceaction.org) on behalf of the community, through the sale of carbon credits. Using the chlorine dispenser generates carbon credits by avoiding the need to boil water to make it safe to drink. The sale of carbon credits, to organizations and individuals wanting to reduce their carbon footprint, will be used to repay Kiva lenders and also to make sure that Dina’s community can have access to safe water now and in the future.

loans.use: To install and maintain chlorine dispensers to provide access to safe drinking water for the community

loans.name: Mary's Group

texts.en:
Mary lives in a home with mud walls, sand or dirt floor, and an iron roof in Chepsahani village in Vihiga, Kenya with her family which includes 4 children. The community of Chepsahani village collects their drinking water from a protected spring because there is no piped water supply in this part of Vihiga Kenya. This water is easily contaminated with bacteria that can cause diarrhea and other water-borne diseases, often making Chepsahani’s inhabitants sick and unable to work or attend school.

A new chlorine dispenser offers a solution to the burden of sickness caused by unsafe drinking water. The dispenser is installed at the local water source, where users turn a valve to add chlorine to their jerricans, then collect water as usual. The chlorine disinfects the water and provides residual protection from recontamination. In Chepsahani, 20 households will benefit from having access to the dispenser and safe water. Mary has volunteered to be the dispenser promoter, who is responsible for refilling the chlorine and encouraging the rest of the community to treat their water and keep themselves and their families healthy. There are four other volunteer promoters from the surrounding community who are part of this group loan: Monica, Jengo, Violet and Aggrey.

Chepsahani village needs a loan to cover the costs of installing and maintaining the dispenser. Mary believes that diseases will be reduced through the program and their lives will be in less risk. The Kiva loan will be repaid by Evidence Action (www.evidenceaction.org) on behalf of the community, through the sale of carbon credits. Using the chlorine dispenser generates carbon credits by avoiding the need to boil water to make it safe to drink. The sale of carbon credits, to organizations and individuals wanting to reduce their carbon footprint, will be used to repay Kiva lenders and also to make sure that Mary’s community can have access to safe water now and in the future.

loans.use: To reduce the burden of water-borne diseases by providing access to safe drinking water via chlorine dispensers

loans.name: Susan's Group

texts.en:
36-year-old Susan lives in Chepterit village in Vihiga, Kenya. She is an active member of the community involved in the Women's group credit and savings group and the burial committee. Chepterit village does not have a piped water supply, so the community collects their water from a protected spring. This water is easily contaminated with bacteria that can cause diarrhea and other water-borne diseases, meaning that Susan and her family may fall sick and become unable to work or attend school.

Susan works as a subsistence farmer growing maize and beans, but has also volunteered her time to be the promoter for a new chlorine dispenser program that enables her community to drink safe water and stay healthy. Susan and other promoters in her community (including: Elizabeth, Jane, Ronica and Timinah) need a loan to cover the costs of installing and maintaining chlorine dispensers at the water sources in the area. Susan will encourage the community to treat their water with the dispenser, and refill the dispenser with chlorine as needed. Susan wants to be a promoter because she believes it is her duty to assist her community for the better. She believes that the dispenser will help to prevent waterborne diseases.

The Kiva loan will be repaid by Evidence Action (www.evidenceaction.org) on behalf of the community, through the sale of carbon credits. Using the chlorine dispenser generates carbon credits by avoiding the need to boil water to make it safe to drink. The sale of carbon credits, to organizations and individuals wanting to reduce their carbon footprint, will be used to repay Kiva lenders and also to make sure that Susan’s community can have access to safe water now and in the future.

loans.use: to provide communities with free access to chlorine to treat their drinking water

loans.name: Wuilmer Group

texts.es:
Jackeline es una mujer emprendedora de 46 años de edad, originaria de la Región del Pacifico de Nicaragua, desde hace 15 años vende diversos productos en Puerto Cabezas. Cuando perdió su trabajo una amiga la motivó venir a probar suerte en Bilwi, particularmente en Sandy Bay por la dinámica comercial. Con su liquidación que obtuvo de su trabajo anterior, compró su primera mercadería. Actualmente junto con su esposo son vendedores ambulantes y venden cosméticos por catálogos, zapatos y ropa usada. A las pulperías les distribuye bolsones de chivería que compra en Managua y los vende a precios accesibles y a los establecimientos de fritangas le distribuye verduras. 

Actualmente solicita financiamiento para comprar un saco de cebolla, una paca de zapatos y ropa usada, un balde de tomate, 40 unidades de repollo. Su mayor anhelo es contar con un tramo propio, para no andar caminando y construir su propia vivienda.

Alba: Tiene una Pulpería en su casa, vende frijoles cocidos y elabora tortillas.  Solicita financiamiento para comprar mercadedira para su negocio. Su sueño es tener su propia vivienda.

Alicia: Desde hace tres meses comenzó su pequeño negocio donde vende huevos, gaseosas, chiverías y frijoles  cocidos.  El préstamo que solicita es para comprar granos básicos para venderlos en su pulpería. Sueña con llegar a tener una tienda más grande donde ofrezca diferentes productos.
texts.en:
Jackeline is a hard working 46 year old woman. She’s originally from the Pacific region of Nicaragua. For the past 15 years she’s been selling various products in Puerto Cabezas. When she lost her job, a friend persuaded her to try her luck in Bilwi, specifically in Sandy Bay, because of the commercial opportunities. With the settlement money she got from her last hob, she bought her start-up merchandise. Now, together with her husband, she travels by foot and sells cosmetics via catalogue, shoes, and used clothing. She sells dairy products that she buys in Managua to local stores at affordable prices, and she sells vegetables to fried food sellers. 

Right now she’s asking for financing to buy a bag of onions, a bale of used clothing and shoes, a bucket of tomatoes, and 40 units of cabbage. She ultimate goal is to have her own sales location so that she doesn’t have to walk and to build her own house. 

Alba: She has a store in her house. She sells cooked beans and makes tortillas. She’s asking for money to buy merchandise for her business. Her dream is to have her own house. 

Alicia: She began a small business three months ago selling eggs, sodas, dairy products, and cooked beans. She’s asking for a loan to buy basic grains to sell in her store. Her dream is to have a bigger store where she can offer a greater variety of products.

loans.use: to  buy a bag of onions, a bale of shoes and used clothing, a bucket of tomatoes, and 40 units of cabbage.

loans.name: Nyamachachona Group

texts.en:
Nyamachachona is a Nuru International group of seven farmers in Kuria West District. The members joined the group to acquire skills and knowledge on improved farming methods. They are able to obtain loans through Nuru to acquire farm inputs. As a group, the members of Nyamachachona collectively guarantee the loan.
Thomas (raising his hand in the photo) is the leader of the group. He is 43 years old and is married with five children who attend school. He has been a member of this group for three years now and has greatly benefited from the group. With the loan package he is going to get this season, Thomas hopes that production will go up. The Kiva loan will enable him obtain fertilizer and hybrid seeds of sorghum, millet and maize; this will play a big role in increasing his farm production.  Thomas just like other members of his group will take input loans for one acre. He will grow maize in 1/2 acre, sorghum and millet in a ¼ acre each. He hopes to get enough food for his family and sell the surplus to obtain money to pay for his children’s school fees.

loans.use: To purchase hybrid seeds and fertilizer to grow maize, sorghum and millet

loans.name: Nguku Kifaru Group

texts.en:
Kifaru is a Nuru International group of five farmers in Kuria West District in Kenya. The members joined the group to acquire skills and knowledge on improved farming methods. They are able to obtain loans through Nuru to acquire farm inputs. As a group, the members of Kifaru collectively guarantee the loan.

Robert is the Chairperson of the group. He is 23 years old, married with one child. The loan from Kiva will enable him obtain hybrid seeds and fertilizer which will enable him practice improved farming methods resulting in high yields. Robert just like other members of his group will take input loans for one acre. He will grow maize in 1/2 acre, sorghum and millet in a ¼ acre each. He will secure enough food for his family and sell the surplus and obtain capital to invest in a local poultry business.

loans.use: To purchase hybrid seeds and fertilizer to grow maize, sorghum and millet.

loans.name: Anonymous

texts.es: la clienta de 20 años de edad vive con su hija, su madre y sus hermanos en casa propia pero no poseen luz eléctrica, ella trabaja como domestica en una casa que se encuentra cerca de su lugar de residencia con lo que obtiene de su trabajo logra solventar algunos gastos de su hogar, ella está solicitando un crédito para la compra de una lámpara solar ya que en la comunidad donde ella reside no poseen luz eléctrica y con lo que gana no le alcanza para poder realizarlo, la lámpara es una estación de carga con energía de paneles solares en forma de lámpara que sirve para los hogares de zonas rurales donde no poseen energía eléctrica que es la que muestra en la fotografia, con esta compra se podrán beneficiar con su familia ya que por las noches podrán tener luz propia.
texts.en:
The client is 20 years old. She lives with her daughter, her mother and her siblings in their own house. It does not have electricity. She works as a domestic in a house that is close to her home. She got the job to be able to pay some of the household expenses.
She is requesting a loan to buy a solar lamp as the community in which she lives does not have electricity and the money she has isn't sufficient to purchase it. The lamp is a charging station that gets it's energy from solar panels which form the lamp. It is designed to serve homes in rural areas that don't have electricity. It is shown in the photograph. With this purchase she can enjoy the benefits along with her family of having their own light at night.

loans.use: to buy a solar light.

loans.name: Fermina

texts.en:
Fermina is a married woman with seven children. She is a very hardworking entrepreneur. Fermina is 54 years old and has one child who is still in school.

Fermina has a general store business in the Philippines. Fermina requested a 16,000 PHP loan amount through NWTF to buy more stock such as snack foods, soft-drinks, biscuits, canned goods, detergent soap, etc. to sell.

She successfully paid back her previous loan and is now requesting a new loan to further build her general store business.

Fermina has been in this business for four years. Fermina would like to build and expand her business to secure the future of her family.

loans.use: to buy more stock, such as snack foods, soft drinks, biscuits, canned goods, detergent soap, etc. to sell

loans.name: Bernardita

texts.es: Bernardita , tiene la edad de 53 años, está casada y actualmente vive con su esposo y su madre. Ella con el crédito va comprar una novillas para meterlas en su propiedad. Ella cuentan con terrenos de repastos aptos para le explotación de este proyecto. Ella lo que quiere es producir leche y sacar queso y otros productos para luego venderlos y generar más ingresos para el bienestar de su familia y minimizar el peso de las responsabilidad de su esposo con los gastos.  Es el primer  préstamo que  recibido de FUDECOSUR. Ella no había tenido antes otros préstamos en bancos estatales, pero FUDECOSUR le ha brindado el préstamo con mayores facilidades y la tasa de intereses mucho más baja.
texts.en:
Bernadita is 53 years old. She is married and currently lives with her husband and mother. With this loan she is going to buy heifers to put on her property. She tells us that she has sufficient pasture land to carry out this project. She hopes to produce milk and cheese and other dairy products to later sell and generate income for the well-being of her family, and to minimize the weight of her husband's responsibility with the bills. 

This is her first loan cycle with FUDECOSUR. She has not received any bank loans before in state banks but FUDECOSUR has offered her this loan with greater ease and a much lower rate of interest.

loans.use: to buy heifers.

loans.name: Davit

texts.en:
Davit is 33-year-old married man. He lives with his wife and two children in the small village of Tsalka district. He is involved in the agricultural business from early childhood, as his parents were farmers and this is a traditional activity for the family. 
Sadly, for lack of economic resources and because he had to start working at a very young age, Davit was unable to study a professional career. He works hard on family-owned agricultural land, growing potatoes. He always has high quality products, which are sold to local retailers for a good price. In addition, they own 2 cows, whose milk is used in cheese products. As the family has only seasonal income, Davit decided to start his own stable business and seek for credit among local financial institutions, but his attempts were unsuccessful because of his poor living conditions. The startup program, that is a joint initiative between Kiva and Credo, enables rural poor and inexperienced people to get a loan for starting or re-starting businesses. Davit's application was approved under the framework of this program to get a loan of 2500 Gel for purchasing a minibus. As the minibus is purchased he will get orders to transport cargo to different destinations and increase the income of his family.

loans.use: to purchase a minibus and start working in transportation.

loans.name: Souad

texts.en:
Souad is a 48-year-old married woman, who has been working as a tailor since eight years ago.
She is a hard worker, well known in her region with a good reputation and special talent in her business. Souad works hard to support her husband in their living, to make sure that they'll have a secured financial living in the future while aging with each other.
She is acquiring a loan from Kiva partner Al Majmoua, to buy necessary tailoring machine and tailoring needs that will help her in developing her business and replying to her customers' Christmas needs in a faster way since her current machine isn't working well anymore.
She hopes to expand and develop her business more and move it outside of her house to give both her husband and customers the privacy they deserve to have.

loans.use: To buy necessary tailoring machine and tailoring needs that will help her in developing her business and replying to her customers' Christmas needs more quickly since her current machine isn't working well anymore.

loans.name: Armenuhi

texts.en:
Armenuhi is 38. She lives in Vanadzor town with her daughter and husband. Over the last 5 years, Armenuhi has been involved in the retail business. She resells clothing and dressmaking supplies. She brings clothing from Yerevan and resells it from her house. Due to the hard work that Armenuhi is doing, she is well known among locals who prefer to purchase clothing accessories from Armenuhi.
Currently, for being able to purchase new stock of clothing, Armenuhi needs financial support. She asks this loan for being able to purchase stock of clothing and resell it to her customers. She has been approved for a loan within the framework of a new joint initiative between Kiva and SEF international. The start-up loan program provides business start-up loans with soft conditions to informal businesses that do not have access to credit products. The loan will be a big help for Armenuhi, and will give her an opportunity to continue and enlarge her retail business.

loans.use: to pay for new stock of clothing for reselling it to customers.

loans.name: Uracan Group

texts.es:
Es un grupo conformado por tres mujeres; se caracterizan por poseer un espíritu emprendedor y muestran entusiasmo en el trabajo que realizan. Este grupo es originario de Bilwi y están comenzando a trabajar solidariamente.

Florencia, tiene 45 años de edad, es originaria de la Ciudad de Bilwi,  madre de 5 hijos, tres adultos y dos adolescentes que van a la escuela. Habita en una pequeña vivienda de madera, con sus hijos, nietos y con apoyo de su esposo desde hace tres años comenzó su pequeño negocio en el mercado de Bilwi. Vende artículos plásticos y ropa para niñas y mujeres que ella misma confecciona.  Solicita financiamiento para comprar en Managua 2 docenas de vasos plásticos y de vidrios, media docena de Panas, media docena de escoba, rastrillo, telas para confeccionar togas y birretes en esta época de promociones escolares, por lo que espera incrementar su clientela y vender sus productos a precios accesibles. 

Dionicia: Tiene una pequeña pulpería en el mercado, donde vende verduras, granos básicos y chiverías. Solicita financiamiento para comprar más productos en Managua y diversificar con utensilios de cocina. Su sueño es que su negocio vaya creciendo.

Kenia: Vende ropa usada desde 3 años en un pequeño tramo en el mercado de Bilwi. El préstamo que solicita es para comprar una paca de zapatos usados y una paca de ropa usada para vender en su negocio. Sueña con llegar a tener una tienda de ropa nueva para niños y tener su propia casa.
texts.en:
This group is made up of three woman of an enterprising spirit and who demonstrate enthusiasm in the work they do. The group is native to Bilwi and have begun to work together. 

Florencia is 45 years old. She is native to Bilwi and has five children, three of them adults and two who attend school. She lives in a small wooden house with her children and grandchildren and with the help of her husband, she started a small business in the Bilwi market  three years ago. She sells plastic goods and clothing for women and children, which she makes herself. She is requesting this loan to buy in Managua two dozen plastic and glass vases, half a dozen pairs of corduroy pants, half a dozen brooms, rakes, clothes to make gowns and mortarboards for this graduation season. She hopes to increase her clientele and sell her products at accessible prices.

Dionicia has a small store in the market where she sells vegetables, basic grains and spices. She needs the loan to buy more products in Managua and to diversify by selling kitchen utensils. She hopes to expand her business.

Kenia is a 25 year old native of Bilwa, is married and has a son who is still a minor. She has sold used clothing for the past three years in a small section of the Bilwi market. She will use the loan to buy a bundle of used shoes and a bale of used clothing to sell in her business. She dreams of having a store to sell new clothing for children and of owning her own home.

loans.use: to buy merchandise such as kitchen and cleaning supplies and material for clothing in Managua for her business.
